required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Slippers to Reduce Transfer From Floors to Surfaces
clinical_study.official_title: Impact of Wearing Slippers on Transfer of Bacteriophage MS2 From Floors in Patient Rooms to Bedding and Surfaces

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this study is to determine if wearing slippers will reduce transfer of bacteriophage MS2 from hospital room floors to surfaces in the room and hands of patients. Subjects are randomized to wear slippers versus standard care and cultures are collected at 24 and 48 hours to assess transfer of bacteriophage MS2 from the floor to high-touch surfaces, personal items, bedding, socks or feet, and hands of patients.

detailed_description.textblock: The goal of this study is to determine if wearing slippers will reduce transfer of bacteriophage MS2 from hospital room floors to surfaces in the room and hands of patients. Hospitalized patients are enrolled and randomized to wear slippers any time they are out of bed versus standard care. Bacteriophage MS2 is inoculated onto a site on the floor between the patient bed and the bathroom. Cultures are collected at 24 and 48 hours to assess transfer of bacteriophage MS2 from the floor to high-touch surfaces (bed rail, bedside table, telephone, call button), personal items, bedding, socks or feet, and hands of patients.

study_design_info.masking_description: Lab personnel processing cultures blinded to the study group

primary_outcome.measure: Contamination of a composite of high-touch surfaces, personal items, socks/feet, bedding, and hands

arm_group.description: Patients wear slippers any time they are out of bed with a goal of avoiding any contact between socks/feet and the floor
Patients receive standard care with no intervention

intervention.description: Patients in the intervention group wear slippers when out of bed

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients of 18 years of age or older
- Ambulatory
- Able to demonstrate an understanding of study procedures
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unable or unwilling to fulfill study requirements.
- Expected length of stay less than 48 hours
- Any patient deemed not suitable for study participation at the discretion of the study investigator

patient_data.ipd_description: We will provide de-identified individual participant data to those who provide a request in writing.
